problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items with their dimensions

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used in the end to pack all all items. Minimizing it is the objective.
Which item is assigned to which box as a separate variable.
Position x and y of each item within box as a separate variable.

constraints:
# -- Constraints --


# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def fit_items_in_box(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    box_width: int,
    box_height: int
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Ensure items fit within the box dimensions
        assert assignments[i].x + items[i].width <= box_width
        assert assignments[i].y + items[i].height <= box_height
        # Ensure positions are non-negative
        assert assignments[i].x >= 0
        assert assignments[i].y >= 0
        # Ensure box_id is positive
        assert assignments[i].box_id >= 1

fit_items_in_box(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

# Set redundant fields equal
for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
    assert item_box_assignments[i].box_id == x_y_positions[i].box_id
    assert item_box_assignments[i].x == x_y_positions[i].x
    assert item_box_assignments[i].y == x_y_positions[i].y

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap_constraints(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check items assigned to the same box
            if assignments[i].box_id == assignments[j].box_id:
                # Check for non-overlapping rectangles
                assert (
                    assignments[i].x + items[i].width <= assignments[j].x or
                    assignments[j].x + items[j].width <= assignments[i].x or
                    assignments[i].y + items[i].height <= assignments[j].y or
                    assignments[j].y + items[j].height <= assignments[i].y
                )

no_overlap_constraints(ITEMS, item_box_assignments)

# Set redundant fields equal
for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
    assert item_box_assignments[i].box_id == x_y_positions[i].box_id
    assert item_box_assignments[i].x == x_y_positions[i].x
    assert item_box_assignments[i].y == x_y_positions[i].y

# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def ensure_item_box_assignment_validity(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),

    box_height: int
):

        # Ensure items fit within the box dimensions
        assert assignments[i].x + items[i].width <= box_width
        assert assignments[i].y + items[i].height <= box_height
        # Ensure positions are non-negative
        assert assignments[i].x >= 0
        assert assignments[i].y >= 0
        # Ensure box_id is positive
        assert assignments[i].box_id >= 1

ensure_item_box_assignment_validity(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

# Set redundant fields equal
for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
    assert item_box_assignments[i].box_id == x_y_positions[i].box_id
    assert item_box_assignments[i].x == x_y_positions[i].x
    assert item_box_assignments[i].y == x_y_positions[i].y

# --- Objects ---


# Object type for items with width and height
Item = DSRecord({
    "width": DSInt(lb=1, ub=40),
    "height": DSInt(lb=1, ub=40)
})

# Object type for box assignments and positions
BoxAssignment = DSRecord({
    "box_id": DSInt(lb=1, ub=20),
    "x": DSInt(lb=0, ub=40),
    "y": DSInt(lb=0, ub=40)
})



# --- Constants and Decision Variables ---
BOX_HEIGHT : int = 40
BOX_WIDTH : int = 40
ITEMS : DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item) = [{"width": 27, "height": 34}, {"width": 19, "height": 18}, {"width": 11, "height": 4}, {"width": 34, "height": 35}, {"width": 26, "height": 26}, {"width": 7, "height": 7}, {"width": 7, "height": 21}, {"width": 35, "height": 19}, {"width": 5, "height": 29}, {"width": 17, "height": 27}, {"width": 11, "height": 31}, {"width": 5, "height": 2}, {"width": 30, "height": 17}, {"width": 24, "height": 27}, {"width": 7, "height": 28}, {"width": 9, "height": 27}, {"width": 4, "height": 9}, {"width": 11, "height": 4}, {"width": 26, "height": 21}, {"width": 21, "height": 9}]
N_ITEMS : int = 20
nr_used_boxes : DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)
item_box_assignments : DSList(length=20, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
x_y_positions : DSList(length=20, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
N_ITEMS : int = 20
N_ITEM_BOX_ASSIGNMENTS : int = 20
N_X_Y_POSITIONS : int = 20


# --- objective ---
def calculate_objective(assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=BoxAssignment)) -> DSInt(lb=1, ub=20):
    max_box_id: int = 0
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        if assignments[i].box_id > max_box_id:
            max_box_id = assignments[i].box_id
    return max_box_id

objective = calculate_objective(item_box_assignments)
nr_used_boxes = objective
minimize(objective)

# -- Constraints --


# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def fit_items_in_boxes(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    box_width: int,
    box_height: int
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Ensure items fit within the box dimensions
        assert assignments[i].x + items[i].width <= box_width
        assert assignments[i].y + items[i].height <= box_height
        # Ensure positions are non-negative
        assert assignments[i].x >= 0
        assert assignments[i].y >= 0
        # Ensure box_id is positive
        assert assignments[i].box_id >= 1

fit_items_in_boxes(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

# Equality constraints for redundant fields between item_box_assignments and x_y_positions
for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
    assert item_box_assignments[i].box_id == x_y_positions[i].box_id
    assert item_box_assignments[i].x == x_y_positions[i].x
    assert item_box_assignments[i].y == x_y_positions[i].y

# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    box_width: int,
    box_height: int
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i].box_id == assignments[j].box_id:
                # Check for non-overlapping on x-axis
                x_no_overlap: bool = (assignments[i].x + items[i].width <= assignments[j].x) or \
                                     (assignments[j].x + items[j].width <= assignments[i].x)
                # Check for non-overlapping on y-axis
                y_no_overlap: bool = (assignments[i].y + items[i].height <= assignments[j].y) or \
                                     (assignments[j].y + items[j].height <= assignments[i].y)
                # Assert that at least one axis has no overlap
                assert x_no_overlap or y_no_overlap

no_overlap(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def ensure_item_assignment_consistency(
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        assert assignments[i].box_id == positions[i].box_id
        assert assignments[i].x == positions[i].x
        assert assignments[i].y == positions[i].y

ensure_item_assignment_consistency(item_box_assignments, x_y_positions)

    assert item_box_assignments[i].x == x_y_positions[i].x

):

        assert positions[i].y + items[i].height <= BOX_HEIGHT
        
        # Ensure assigned box id matches position record

        assert positions[i].y >= 0

    assert item_box_assignments[i].box_id <= 20
    assert x_y_positions[i].box_id >= 1
    assert x_y_positions[i].box_id <= 20

    assert item_box_assignments[i].x == x_y_positions[i].x
    assert item_box_assignments[i].y == x_y_positions[i].y
    assert item_box_assignments[i].box_id == x_y_positions[i].box_id

def no_overlap(
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item)
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check overlap if both items are in the same box
            if positions[i].box_id == positions[j].box_id:
                # Check if rectangles overlap
                assert (
                    positions[i].x + items[i].width <= positions[j].x or
                    positions[j].x + items[j].width <= positions[i].x or
                    positions[i].y + items[i].height <= positions[j].y or
                    positions[j].y + items[j].height <= positions[i].y
                )

no_overlap(x_y_positions, ITEMS)

    assert item_box_assignments[i].x == x_y_positions[i].x
    assert item_box_assignments[i].y == x_y_positions[i].y

    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        assert assignments[i].box_id == positions[i].box_id
        assert assignments[i].x == positions[i].x
        assert assignments[i].y == positions[i].y

ensure_item_box_assignment_consistency(item_box_assignments, x_y_positions)

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items with their dimensions

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used in the end to pack all all items. Minimizing it is the objective.
Which item is assigned to which box as a separate variable.
Position x and y of each item within box as a separate variable.

        # Ensure item fits within the box dimensions

        assert assignments[i].y + items[i].height <= box_height
        # Ensure item is placed within valid coordinate range
        assert assignments[i].x >= 0
        assert assignments[i].y >= 0

ensure_items_fit_in_boxes(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

    assert item_box_assignments[i].x == x_y_positions[i].x

    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),

):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):

                # Check for non-overlapping on x-axis
                x_not_overlap: bool = (assignments[i].x + items[i].width <= assignments[j].x) or \

                # Check for non-overlapping on y-axis
                y_not_overlap: bool = (assignments[i].y + items[i].height <= assignments[j].y) or \

                # Assert that at least one axis does not overlap (i.e., items do not overlap)
                assert x_not_overlap or y_not_overlap

    assert item_box_assignments[i].x == x_y_positions[i].x
    assert item_box_assignments[i].y == x_y_positions[i].y

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items with their dimensions

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used in the end to pack all all items. Minimizing it is the objective.
Which item is assigned to which box as a separate variable.
decision_variables.initialization: item_box_assignments: Annotated[list[Annotated[int, Field(strict=True, ge=1, le=20)]], Len(20, 20)]

decision_variables.description: Position x and y of each item within box as a separate variable.

        box_id: int = item_box_assignments[i]
        if box_id > max_box_id:
            max_box_id = box_id
    return max_box_id

objective = calculate_objective(item_box_assignments)
nr_used_boxes = objective
minimize(objective)

                       (positions[j].x + items[j].width <= positions[i].x) or \
                       (positions[i].y + items[i].height <= positions[j].y) or \
                       (positions[j].y + items[j].height <= positions[i].y)

no_overlap(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, x_y_positions)

def no_overlap(

# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap_constraints(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    item_box_assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)),
    x_y_positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position)
):
    # Constraint: Items in the same box must not overlap
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check items that are in the same box
            if item_box_assignments[i] == item_box_assignments[j]:
                # Ensure items do not overlap
                # They overlap if both rectangles intersect
                # Rectangle i: [x_y_positions[i].x, x_y_positions[i].x + items[i].width) x [x_y_positions[i].y, x_y_positions[i].y + items[i].height)
                # Rectangle j: [x_y_positions[j].x, x_y_positions[j].x + items[j].width) x [x_y_positions[j].y, x_y_positions[j].y + items[j].height)

                # x_y_positions[i].y + items[i].height <= x_y_positions[j].y OR x_y_positions[j].y + items[j].height <= x_y_positions[i].y
                assert (
                    x_y_positions[i].x + items[i].width <= x_y_positions[j].x or
                    x_y_positions[j].x + items[j].width <= x_y_positions[i].x or
                    x_y_positions[i].y + items[i].height <= x_y_positions[j].y or

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check for overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i] == assignments[j]:
                # Extracting values for readability; however, per rules, these should be inlined.
                # So we avoid creating auxiliary variables for simple field access.
                # Instead, directly use the expressions in the assertions below.
                
                # Conditions for non-overlapping rectangles:
                # Rectangles do not overlap if one is completely to the left, right, above, or below the other.
                # That gives us four conditions, at least one of which must be true for no overlap.
                # We negate this to get a condition for overlap and assert that it's false (i.e., not(true) => false).
                # But since we want to assert NO OVERLAP, we need the disjunction of the non-overlapping cases.
                # Non-overlapping cases:
                # 1. item i is to the left of item j: pos_i.x + width_i <= pos_j.x
                # 2. item j is to the left of item i: pos_j.x + width_j <= pos_i.x
                # 3. item i is below item j: pos_i.y + height_i <= pos_j.y
                # 4. item j is below item i: pos_j.y + height_j <= pos_i.y
                
                # Using direct expressions in the assertion as per rule 6
                assert (
                    positions[i].x + items[i].width <= positions[j].x or
                    positions[j].x + items[j].width <= positions[i].x or
                    positions[i].y + items[i].height <= positions[j].y or
                    positions[j].y + items[j].height <= positions[i].y
                )

no_overlap(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments)

):

        assert assignments[i] >= 1
        assert assignments[i] <= 20

ensure_item_box_assignment_validity(item_box_assignments)

def calculate_objective(assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))) -> DSInt(lb=0, ub=20):

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items with their dimensions

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used in the end to pack all all items. Minimizing it is the objective.
Which item is assigned to which box as a separate variable.
decision_variables.initialization: item_box_assignments: Annotated[list[Annotated[int, Field(strict=True, ge=1, le=20)]], Len(20, 20)]

decision_variables.description: Position x and y of each item within box as a separate variable.
